Pre-Game Insights: India’s current 10-match winning streak in T20Is has only ever been bettered by Afghanistan (twice).
Sri Lanka are 3-time T20 World Cup finalists, having beaten India in the 2014 final, but it’s been a steep decline since then.
The absences of Virat Kohli and Rishabh Pant – both rested – and Deepak Chahar and Suryakumar Yadav, who were injured against the West Indies, means more chances for those on the fringes.
Sri Lanka’s absence of Wanindu Hasaranga due to Covid-19 is a further blow.
Teams batting first have won 4 out of 6 completed games at Dharamsala, but due to the low sample size and inclusion of weaker teams, it's hard to draw conclusions.
Miscellaneous Highlights: It’s still winter in Dharamsala with temperatures dropping to as low as 6°C during the game.
There is a likelihood of rain earlier in the day and during the game.
Dharamsala hasn't hosted a T20I in nearly 6 years, with only 6 completed matches, including teams like Oman and Ireland.
Moisture in the air suggests bowling first might be advantageous if rain affects the match.
Ishan Kishan has a strike rate of 122.42 in his 9 T20Is but showed potential with 3 sixes and 10 fours in the opening game.
Yuzvendra Chahal is India’s leading T20 wicket-taker with 67 wickets, including 16 against Sri Lanka, but his economy rate is slightly high in those games.
Charith Asalanka scored an unbeaten 53 in the first game and is one of Sri Lanka’s brightest batting prospects.
Lahiru Kumara has taken 41 wickets in 36 T20Is with an economy rate of 8.36, recently taking 2/22 against Australia.

The Howzat Dream Team includes Ishan Kishan as the wicketkeeper, Rohit Sharma, Shreyas Iyer, and Charith Asalanka as batters, Venkatesh Iyer, Ravindra Jadeja, Dasun Shanaka, and Chamika Karunaratne as all-rounders, and Yuzvendra Chahal, Harshal Patel, and Lahiru Kumara as bowlers.
